subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] international quikscript
msgSnippet: ... I m now thinking that the small number of NORTH words should be written Owe + Roe rather than Awe + Roe, to accommodate people who do make the distinction:
messageBody:
peter_r_guinness scripsit:

> FORCE = 33 Awe + 25 Roe
> NORTH = 33 Awe + 25 Roe

I'm now thinking that the small number of NORTH words should be written
Owe + Roe rather than Awe + Roe, to accommodate people who do make the
distinction: speakers in Scotland, Ireland, the Caribbean, and parts of
the U.S.

Words spelled in -or, and some words in -orC- (where C means any consonant
sound) are NORTH; words in -oar-, -our-, -ore-, etc. are FORCE. There are
exceptions: fork is NORTH but pork is FORCE.

If you look up words in the online American Heritage Dictionary at
http://bartleby.com/61 , the NORTH words have one pronunciation using
"ôr", whereas the FORCE words have two pronunciations, one with "ôr"
(o-circumflex) and a second one with "ōr" (o-macron).

> I would like to know what other people think about using 'Eat' instead
> of 'It' for the happY set.

I'm for it. The distinction between Eat and It in final position is
fully neutralized (it never separates two words), most anglophones now
use Eat, and ongoing changes are in the It > Eat direction. The only
reason to keep It is, ironically, conservatism.

> I would also like to know what people think about the distinction
> between 'Way' (18) and 'Why' (20) - should they be merged, optional
> distinction or kept distinct?

I'd say keep it, on the same grounds as the NORTH/FORCE distinction.

--
[W]hen I wrote it I was more than a little John Cowan
febrile with foodpoisoning from an antique carrot cowan@...
that I foolishly ate out of an illjudged faith http://ccil.org/~cowan
in the benignancy of vegetables. --And Rosta
